--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Richard Gong <gongrichard@...> wrote:
>
> Wh=
at real world problems have been successfully solved by NEAT?
> 
> Like Col=
in Green, I have tried to apply NEAT to finance, but without
> success.
>

=
One recent interesting real-world success is the most accurate measurement =
yet of the top quark mass at the Fermilab accelerator:

Aaltonen et al. Mea=
surement of the Top Quark Mass with Dilepton Events Selected using Neuroevo=
lution at CDF. Physical Review Letters, 102(15):2001=962008, 2009.
http://w=
ww-cdf.fnal.gov/physics/preprints/cdf9235_dil_mtop_nn.pdf

Believe it or no=
t, NEAT is the method that was used to get the reading.  Physical Review Le=
tters is a top physics journal.  If you search Google for : Top Quark "augm=
enting topologies"
you will see a lot written about it.

However, often suc=
h results say more about the ability of someone to choose the right problem=
 for the method than it does about the method overall.  AI and neural-inspi=
red learning methods are clearly a work in progress, so a lot of the excite=
ment is in the ideas and where they may lead, rather than a particular appl=
ication.

Also, when it comes to finance, perhaps neurological accuracy is =
not the best basis for mastering it.  After all, most people are not able t=
o look at a graph of financial activity and know what will happen next, yet=
 they are great at tying their shoes.  Of course, in the context of the rec=
ent financial meltdown, it's not clear that anything or anyone is really go=
od at finance.

ken
